"Mental discomfort. Clashing beliefs.
Cognitive dissonance describes the stress your brain feels when your actions and beliefs don’t match.

Imagine you love animals but eat meat.
Your brain notices the contradiction—‘This doesn’t add up’—and pushes you to change something.
You might stop eating meat, or convince yourself farming is ‘humane. ’
Either way, the discomfort fades.

A famous test gave people $1 to lie about a boring task.
Later, they rated the task as more fun than those paid $20.
Why?
The $1 group needed a bigger excuse—‘Maybe it wasn’t so bad’—to justify their lie.

This effect shapes habits, politics, even addictions.
Smokers downplay health risks.
Fans defend flawed teams.
The brain prefers consistency over truth.

Three related subjects are confirmation bias, self-justification traps, and cult deprogramming methods. "
